comments.commentBody:
When normal politicians change their minds we label it flip-flopping or – more kindly – “evolving” in their thinking. When a Master Persuader does it, you are seeing pacing and leading.

a. Trump paced his base by saying he would deport 11 million undocumented immigrants. Once he had his base on his side emotionally, he led to them to his current policy of deporting only the people who committed crimes while here. Have you heard any Trump supporters complain about it lately?

b. Trump paced his base by saying he would ban all Muslim immigration to stop terrorist infiltration. Once he had them on his side emotionally, he led them first to a ban on specific problem countries, and then again to “extreme vetting,” which is a lot like Clinton’s plan. Trump supporters followed, and you don’t hear them complaining.

c. Early in the primaries Trump paced the racists in the Republican party by not disavowing them as clearly and as loudly as even the racists thought he would. Since then he has led Republicans to think that some form of a “New Deal” for African-Americans might be worth a look.

In my opinion, Trump might be the safest president we have ever had. He can lead the dark parts of his base toward the light (as Nixon went to China) and he has no incentive for war. Claims about his “temperament” are mostly about his penchant for insults, and that isn’t a mortal danger to anyone.

He's not counting Charlotte as a red area but Charlotte's outer suburbs, which, like affluent, well-educated exurbs generally, tend to be socially moderate, disproportionately concerned about "crime," and strongly tax-averse.

From Nixon to Bush II, taxes and "crime" tended to win out, but the youngest, best-educated and wealthiest exurbanites broke hard for Obama in 2008 and were still holding on in 2012. While it's unlikely they feel as much warmth toward Clinton, they loathe Trump, and their still Republican-leaning, generally more church-going neighbors, the ones who stuck by Romney in 2012, are the biggest wild card in the race. They don't like Trump, don't like Clinton, don't like the Democratic Party or the President, don't like white nationalists (or the Tea Partiers before them), don't like taxes or the ACA, don't like overt racism or sexual assault, and are still disproportionately afraid of "crime."

What will they do? They couldn't make it over for Obama in 2008 but were in the 70-80% of people who approved of him in January 2009. They are much less worried about homosexuality than they used to be but they're still staunchly opposed to abortion. They're skeptical of welfare programs but care about public education and skeptical of the federal government but have faith in the country's institutions and traditions.

They're capital R Republicans, maybe lowercase conservatives, but because they don't want to burn the house down, they have nowhere to live.

I'm surprised that you're counting Charlotte, NC as a red area. Charlotte was where they passed the controversial ordinance women allowing people to use bathrooms of the sex they identify with. It was a hotly contested issue and the vote was close but ultimately liberal. It'll be interesting to see if that vote was an anomaly or if the population metrics have changed.

Interesting to note that Trump can't pull in the Republican base. Shows that the Republican base may not be the hatemongering fools they're often painted as.

I, myself a conservative, usually vote Republican because they are closer to my ideology. Trump isn't getting my vote, precisely because of the outlandish thing he has said. I have no idea where his beliefs fall relative to mine. McCullough gets my vote. Used to be Gary Johnson, but that ship has sailed.

Endless daily emails for money. Endless, endless, endless expenses to supposedly woo voters that can't make up there minds and whose votes are expected to make the differences. What a waste the US elections have become

The current 4-way polls show that Donald Trump is winning support, but not at the expense of Clinton. About half of his gains are winning back Republicans from Gary Johnson and the other half are from gaining non-responsive/undecided voters.

Clinton's support has remained steady across all polls.

replies.commentBody:
Nate Silver at 538 has explained the primary difference between their probabilities. 538 uses a much stronger correlation factor between similar states, while Upshot uses a weaker correlation. The Princeton Election Consortium uses a much weaker correlation, and almost assumes that each state moves independently.

The interesting improvement this election is adding in surveys of early voters drawn from lists of voter names realized by early vote states like Florida. TargetSmart did this in Florida and found 28% of Rs crossed over to vote Clinton, while only 6% of Ds crossed to vote Trump. This is with 3.6 million votes cast so far, in a state that in 2012 cast about 8.6 million. They forecast Clinton wins Florida by 48-40.

comments.commentBody: Mr. Cohn, I really wish you would tell us how you develop your winning probabilities. Where is your description of your methodology, as the other Nate provides (to a limited extent; he doesn't want to give away all of his secrets) on his web site (FiveThirtyEight.com)? At a minimum, pleae tell us why his probability of Clinton's winning is always substantially less than yours. The world wonders. Thank you.
